posts.com:
I think it's pretty obvious at this point that the ancient Egyptians as we know them (Pharoahs, and kings), are not the creators of their pyramids, or of many of the artifacts they take credit for.

They drilled granite in fewer rotations on a drill than we can manage in a day. They have fabricated and polished shapes out of stone using some kind of machining tech we cannot match to this day.

The society that was around back then would've had access to steel and whatnot to build with.

They built the pyramids (or at least, some of the parts) to last. Out of precisely cut or otherwise formed granite.

Why did they build these structures to last so long? It's not an energy collector or some shit. If that was the case they would've built it out of some material easy to work and maintained it regularly. No point in building a permanent structure for energy production and transmission. If you're around to need it, you'll be around to maintain it.

I think these were monuments built to last through a cataclysm, as some kind of sign for the next civilization, which they knew would eventually arise. Some kind of warning, or maybe just a desperate attempt to not be forgotten.

Lots of calendars indicate regular resets. Who's to say there weren't efforts to make it past the reset? What for?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Picrel would be difficult to machine to this day, yet has crude inscriptions from some of the first kings of Egypt. This disk must have been created long ago, lost in some kind of event, then found by the first kings.

This tells us that the first kings (and likely, later Pharoahs) were not the creators of structures that required seemingly impossible-at-the-time tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This granite jar was not formed from clay. It was machined from a single piece of granite. You can see the center has been cored out by a drill, and the grooves from the cutting edge are clear.

The very distinct separation between each groove indicates that this cut must have been moving at the same rate as the blade pitch on the drill. In other words, a pitch of 1mm would meant 1mm depth of cut per rotation.

Even with diamond tipped drills today, it takes several thousand rotations and tons of pressure to cut granite. It can not be done so easily.

How did I1 become Germanic?

From 2800 BCE, a large-scale cultural and genetic upheaval hit Scandinavia with the arrival of the Indo-Europeans from Eastern Europe, who introduced the Copper Age and Early Bronze Age to the region practically without Neolithic transition. The first Indo-Europeans to reach Scandinavia were the Corded Ware people from modern Russia, Belarus and Poland, who are thought to have belonged predominantly to haplogroup R1a, with a minority of R1b and I2a. These people shared some similar maternal lineages as Scandinavian I1 inhabitants, including mtDNA haplogroups U2e, U4 and U5, but also brought many new lineages such as H2a1, H6, W and various subclades of I, J, K and T.

The second major Indo-European migration to Scandinavia was that of haplogroup R1b-U106, the branch that is thought to have introduced Proto-Germanic languages, as an offshoot of the Proto-Celto-Germanic speakers from Central Europe. R1b probably entered Scandinavia from present-day Germany as a northward expansion of the late Unetice culture (2300-1600 BCE). The oldest known R1b sample in Scandinavia dates from the Nordic Bronze Age circa 1400 BCE (see Allentoft 2015 above).

According to the Germanic substrate hypothesis, first proposed by Sigmund Feist in 1932, Proto-Germanic was a hybrid language mixing Indo-European (R1b, and to a lower extent R1a) and pre-Indo-European (Mesolithic I2 and Neolithic G2a and I1) elements. This hybridisation would have taken place during the Bronze Age and given birth to the first Proto-Germanic civilization, the Nordic Bronze Age (1700-500 BCE)

>>33868440
Geologist checking in. These ancient civilizations and their ability to work with hard rocks like granite has always interested me, and it's clear that archeologists are either not being honest or not bothering to check in with geologists and mechanics. That being said, I think I have figured out how they did this and I actually think it was more of a chemistry feat than a mechanical one (though obviously some sort of drill was involved, I just don't think it had to have been particularly complex).
I think that both they and at least the civilization before the Incas managed to make a fairly concentrated hydrofluoric acid. There are plants this can be sourced from and it's possible to store it in glass without significant corrosion to the container. The hydrofluoric acid would have been able to soften the rock, and applications of wax around areas they did not want to be softened would have allowed for some extreme precision. This could have also allowed for very nice polishing depending on how they used it and with what tools. This would unsurprisingly not leave behind much evidence, as it wouldn't last long the moment its container cracked or leaked, and finding glass in full pieces is extremely rare due to its fragility.
The only question for the Egyptians would be what plants they sourced this from, and the process they used to concentrate it. I can say for certain that in South America e.g., Peru, plants that can be used to source hydrofluoric acid are available. It would be a matter of investigative experimentation to figure out how they concentrated this and applied it, but considering the complex methods we know that all cultures have managed to use plant materials, it's safe to assume they figured that out.
I'll try to find some pictures of the quarry evidence I'm talking about, where you can clearly see that hard rock was somehow "scooped" away from desired pieces as if it had been softened into more of a clay or mud for extraction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33879398
Adding in, they could have also done this without significant damage to tools despite its corrosive nature, because they probably would have had to let whatever solution they had sit on the exposed area for some time for it to work (its likely this was more of a pulpy puree rather than a pure liquid, as this would have been easier to work with, and would make more sense starting from plants). It probably wasn't as corrosive as concentrated hydrofluoric acid like what we have today, but basic refining could have gotten a plant-based solution to something potent enough to corrode rock like granite if they applied it multiple times and let it sit for let's say, 20 mins to 1hr each application.
From there, they could work quickly enough to not significantly damage stone tools, at least enough to get a project done. To be fair, if they had this method and were using stone tools (or at least stone for where the tool made contact), making new tools probably wasn't too much of an issue.
I'm not sure about metals like bronze since my run-ins with hydrofluoric acid in the lab were usually me wiping a spill with a towel by instinct and watching my towel disappear kek. It definitely didn't immediately react with the steel countertops enough to do damage.

We still use hydrofluoric acid + wax today as a method to etch designs into things like ceramics; homeowners with granite countertops will urge you to not cut lemons directly on the surface or use acid cleaners due to the damage it can cause - though granite and quartzite are much stronger than something like calcite (marble), it's still a porous rock and needs to be sealed to prevent this kind of corrosion over time.

posts.name: Anonymous

Last note - hydrofluoric acid isn't even the only thing they could have used to get similar results. Here's a good example of granite getting absolutely demolished within a relatively short (geologically) timespan just due to different oxides and compounds in its surrounding environment:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCBxYZ9Hggk&ab_channel=Baker%27sTravertinePowerClean
I just think that hydrofluoric acid is a good contender for something they could have used since it's much faster acting and can be used with precision without complex machinery.
I think that the Egyptians and other ancient civilizations have already proven that they had an excellent understanding of chemistry in real-life applications like this.

>>33875454
Every night before bed I have a mantra / thought, I usually only have to say it once in my head but you can do it however much you want
>My day was perfect
Then you assume that your day was perfect. There's nothing you need to change, you don't need to convince yourself of anything, look at your day and say "I did that" and be proud.
>B-but what if it's bad?
It wasn't, it was perfect, it was exactly as you intended it to be. Everything works out as you want, your day was perfect.

Start thinking about the internal state and not caring about the external, what was your day yesterday and what is your day today? If yesterday was negative and you took a single step towards the positive you have made a significant improvement and your day is perfect, continually making those positive changes means you're certain to be more and more positive every day.
It's a journey, don't worry about the destination but about the process. Feel happy that in the moment you are happy, don't worry about the negative, do not fight it and instead don't care.

I felt a huge wave of negativity randomly telling me that everything was hopeless, you know what I did? I instantly discarded the thought as something I don't think, just another intrusive thought. Read up on intrusive thoughts, everyone has them and you are overstressing over "negative thoughts", intrusive thoughts aren't mine, don't affect me, and aren't even real lmao.

posts.com:
DAILY REMINDER - GPS absolutely proves globe Earth, rotating Earth, space, orbiting satellites, time dilation (relativity), and gravity.

Flerfers will point to LORAN and claim that GPS could work off of transmitters sitting on the ground, on balloons, or on airplanes. But it cannot.

Why? I'm glad you asked.

In tracking mode GPS receivers use Doppler signal analysis to determine receiver velocity. It is impossible for a transmitter to fake Doppler signal shift across 360°. If the transmitter was lying about its speed, then the receiver would think that it was moving at high mach based on the incorrect Doppler shift in the signal. And since GPS is computed in 3D space from four satellite signals, if the satellites were lying about their positions (altitudes) the resulting location and altitude on the receiver would be off by thousands of miles.

This means that GPS satellites are provably at orbital altitudes and speeds, because GPS could not function at all if the satellites were lying. And if the satellites aren't lying, then space is real. Orbits are real. But the dome is not real. Not unless the satellites punched through it.

What about Earth's shape? GPS receivers use a spherical model of Earth. If Earth was really flat, then receivers would report altitudes literally thousands of miles off. This means Earth really is a sphere.

Furthermore, both Earth's rotation and time dilation must be accounted for in GPS. If either one was not true then, once again, receivers would give obviously false and useless results. That means Earth really is rotating. And time dilation is real. And if both orbits and time dilation are real, that pretty much guarantees that gravity is real.

No single instrument completely shatters all of flat Earth mythology quite like the GPS constellation. It really is a beautiful thing.

posts.com:
CBR Proves Earth's Motion Through Space

The ability to measure the cosmic background radiation (CBR) gives us something the physicists of the early/mid 20th century could only dream of: a universal frame of reference by which to establish if Earth is really moving linearly or if it just appears to be. The CBR permeates all of space. If an object is at rest relative to the CBR then the frequencies observed will be the same in all directions. If an object is moving relative to the CBR, then Doppler shift will reveal in what direction and how fast.

We measured this phenomenon and established Earth's linear motion through space using the COBE satellite in operation from 1989 to 1993. What did we find? That the Earth is definitely moving through the cosmos.

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-fast-is-the-earth-mov/

>In 1989, the COBE satellite was placed in orbit about the earth (again, the earth is the frame of reference!) to measure the long-diluted radiation echo of the birth of our universe. This radiation, which remains from the immensely hot and dense primordial fireball that was our early universe, is known as the cosmic microwave background radiation (CBR). The CBR presently pervades all of space. It is the equivalent of the entire universe "glowing with heat."
>One of COBE's discoveries was that the earth was moving with respect to this CBR with a well-defined speed and direction. Because the CBR permeates all space, we can finally answer the original question fully, using the CBR as the frame of reference.
>The earth is moving with respect to the CBR at a speed of 390 kilometers per second. We can also specify the direction relative to the CBR. It is more fun, though, to look up into the night sky and find the constellation known as Leo (the Lion). The earth is moving toward Leo at the dizzying speed of 390 kilometers per second.

posts.com:
FLERFERS LIE

Take a close look at the attached pic. Flerfers often post it as proof the Earth is flat. Why do I want you to look at it? Because it's a lie.

"The Australian Black Swan" tells you that the maximum line of sight for a 5.5ft tall observer is 2.35 miles. But the cliff is 7.8 miles away. So what's wrong with this flat Earth "proof"? *** Line of sight depends on both observer and target height, as well as on atmospheric refraction. *** The lighthouse is at least 100ft tall which means the visible cliff is at least 400ft tall. LoS for a 5.5ft observer of a 500ft (combined height) target is 35 miles.

What about the oil platforms? Ocean oil platforms have an "air gap" between the ocean and the first deck of 40-60 feet. Observer height was listed as 1ft (camera on the ground?). With a 40ft first deck the line of sight is 10 miles. With a 60ft first deck it's 12 miles. With a 5ft observer and a 60ft first deck it would be 14 miles.

At 6.21 and 9.41 miles you would still see the entire structure above the first deck even if the first deck was only 40ft off the ocean and the camera really was on the ground at 1ft. For the closer platform you would see some structure below the first deck. Note that we see more of the closer rig, proving curvature.

Here's a line of sight calculator: http://www.calculatoredge.com/electronics/lineofsight.htm

>but we're talkin' about muh horizon
>MUH HORIZON IS TOO FAR AWAY!
No it's not. It's between the observer and target in both photos. That's why the observer cannot see the very bottom of the target.

posts.com:
The Box That Killed The Dome

If you remove the lid of a pressurized box of air inside of a vacuum chamber without gravity, the air will violently rush out of the box to fill the vacuum. The air pressure will then be the same at every point in the chamber. It will be the same at the top, bottom, middle, and at all sides. Just like the air pressure in your car tires or a balloon or a SCUBA tank.

This thought experiment debunks the entire flat Earth model. If the air does not cling to the bottom of the chamber, then it certainly would not cling to the bottom of flat Earth. If the air does not leave any part of the chamber still in vacuum, then it certainly would not leave any part of flat Earth in vacuum. And if the air creates equal pressure at all points in the chamber, then certainly the air creates equal pressure at all points in the flat Earth dome.

Yet there is no denying that air thins as you climb in altitude. At 100,000 feet, somewhere near the top of the theorized dome, the air pressure is so low that it is effectively a vacuum.

This alone debunks all of flat Earth.

Note: no flerfer has ever provided a workable answer to this. They immediately sperg out if you even mention it, and rant and rave that the box thought experiment actually kills the globe. The only way they can do this, of course, is to deny gravity. But if gravity doesn't exist then the dome is just as dead. And if it does exist, the globe model works, while the dome remains...dead.

The scientific method is a valuable tool for investigating and understanding the world around us, but like any tool, it has its limitations. It is true that there are complex ontological questions, especially in areas like cosmology and quantum physics, where traditional principles of logic and science may not be enough to explain everything. However, this does not mean that we should abandon the scientific method or that we should accept any theory without question. It is important to keep investigating and looking for new ways to understand the world, even if this means exploring paraconsistent forms of logic.

Regarding the shape of the earth, the scientific evidence is clear that it is spherical, but it is important to remember that personal opinions should be respected, but should not be confused with verified scientific evidence.

Gravity is the effect being proven. If it was the independent variable, that would be Begging The Question.

Well, I then met a new client who looked 30 years younger, and he looked just like the annoying client. Same hairstyle, body type, and the he started to whistle and make the weird noises...but his phone also went off and made an irritating clown jingle. I thought WTF???!!

I'm still trying to figure all of this out.

He ended up drugging her a few times and I guess they would trip out and it might have fucked her up a bit. After that relationship she started looking into weird groups online and got into them pretty heavily. One was like a sci-fi religious based group? Like looking st stuff as if the bible and what not was from aliens instead of humans. Another group was like a doomsday group. Well eventually she found a perfect mix of all these things in this little fringe group online. She ended up buying many plane tickets to travel out to their 'leaders' house. He claimed no one was the leader but clearly he was the one kind of running the group of like 20 people. She tried to convert my mom and dad many times and all growing up my mom tried to keep her in her life but also wanted to shield us from the crazy side. One time when we were in a road trip she broke into our house and replaced my dad's family bible, with this weird manuscript they had. The concept of offspring born to humans and demons was a subject of debate in the Middle Ages, but did not have a widely accepted name. The influential Malleus Maleficarum, which has been described as the major compendium of literature in demonology of the fifteenth century,[6] states that demons, including the incubus and the succubus, are incapable of reproduction:

Moreover, to beget a child is the act of a living body, but devils cannot bestow life upon the bodies they assume; because life formally proceeds only from the soul, and the act of generation is the act of the physical organs which have bodily life. Therefore bodies which are assumed in this way cannot either beget or bear.[7]

Because of this inability to create or nurture life, the method of the creation of a cambion is necessarily protracted. A succubus will have sexual relations with a human male and so acquire a sample of his sperm. This she will then pass on to an incubus, who then corrupts and strengthens the seed. The incubus will, in his turn, transfer this sperm to a human female and thus impregnate her.

Yet it may be said that these devils assume a body not in order that they may bestow life upon it, but that they may by the means of this body preserve human semen, and pass the semen on to another body.[7]

Schizophrenia itself defines a deficiency in a person's ability to engage and balance internal and external belief systems, yet this ability is at the heart of LOA. If anything, true mental illness probably hinders a person's ability to apply LOA.

I like shopping at thrift stores because I can spot great deals. The less fortunate like them because they're inexpensive. Same stores, same products, but I'm a millionaire and they may not even have a home.

There's a reason why many religions advise against substance abuse: a clear and directed mind is the key. We should all seek to help each other out of that single trap. Mental illness is just like a physical illness. Cures exist, people need them, and they deserve it.

>>33865844
Lungs are a physical organ that transform air into something useful for life, through something that is similar to a combustion reaction. O2 + Hydrocarbon = H2O + CO2 + energy. Some magical traditions believe breath is related to fire. And of course, fire needs air to live too, so this is not too far fetched.

The hindus recognize that life is connected to breath. If you stop breathing, you die. If you're alive, you must be breathing. Even plants follow this rule, though they inhale CO2 and exhale O2 in a sort of marvelous reversal. That might explain sacred trees, secret groves, nature worship, etc. They are the necessary flip side of animal (and human) life. Your breath shows a window into your emotional state. A sudden gasp (stress), fast breathing (excitement), slow breathing (relaxion), etc. If you understand this, you can alter your breathing make the connection go the other way. These are breathing exercises.

Anyway, air and earth are present in almost every religion that has gods. As the story usually goes, air + earth create the first man or first god. These concepts are usually named the sky father (or heavenly father) and earth mother (or mother earth). In the old testament, this process is used to create adam rather directly. Clay + breath = adam, the first man. In the new testament, this is where jesus comes from, but more symbolically. The one above all (sky father) + mary (the earthly mother) = jesus. But these stories are everywhere. In any case, women create by having children. Men don't have children, so they create using ideas.

So what does air signify? Life, creation and creativity, ideas, possibility/potential, etc. Basically, look up sky father deities and you'll get the picture.

Larp off for a second here guys.

>>33868923
>I did take psychedelic mushrooms in an attempt to communicate with him again but I'm not sure if it worked - is that an example of a medium you wouldn't recommend?
As far as I know, psychedelic drugs give visions are usually impersonal compared to traditional religious visions. I haven't heard of people using them to contact dead relatives, but I guess it's possible. You usually meet spirits, see things, or have feelings that are just sort of "there", I guess. That doesn't mean they're not important, but it's more like "it's important if its important to you" kind of thing. If it is, then it is.
>What are your thoughts on psychedelics in general? Can they be used to connect with true divinity or are those experiences an illusion?
Yeah, they can contact true divinity sometimes. Most of the times you meet things that are more like flora and fauna. They're just sort of "there". They can tell you incredible things, very important and meaningful things. Sometimes its not that meaningful. But meeting like a full on angel is very rare. And of course directly contacting god or something equivalent is... well, it would be a very overpowering experience. Usually people meet god using psychedelics and it's like "I saw god in the universe" or "The beauty of life was so overwhelming and I couldn't stop crying, I thought I was going to die, and that's when I knew god was real" type stuff. Stories about directly meeting a true final ultimate god (rather than just a mid-level spirit) are rare.
>or are those experiences an illusion?
I think they're just as illusory as anything else in life. Many people have trips and describe it being "more real than real" with 100% sincerity. Maybe they're right. I think the real take away is "Did I learn something useful, or was I just getting high?" If it was useful and you know what you learned was right/true/good, then go with it. Otherwise move on with your life.

posts.com:
You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?

I often have what i would call dreams inbetween normal state and lucid. what i mean is that I'm in first person, kind of conscious, and my actions reflect what I would do/would like to do in that scenario. But at the same time I don't have control over the dream, I can't do things such as materialize whatever I want or manually change the setting, or rather I wouldn't know how to. When I have those I often wake up with an "active" brain, not sure how to say it better, unlike when i'm woke up by an alarm, for example, where i feel sloppy and tired.


Last night I had a dream/nightmare about being abducted. Before you ask, no, it was definitely just a dream and felt like one, i just watched and read too much ufo shit lately. So in this dream there were some ETs and humans collaborating, their goal wasn't necesserely malicious, they were studying and experimenting on humans against their will. The humans helping them seemed to be there to bridge communications and calming or explaining what's going on to the abductees. There was a middle aged short man helping them to take me to their ship, at the start of this i was hiding and then rebelling to them, because who tf wants to be abducted, but i realized there was nothing i could do realistically, so i thought to just cooperate and minimize the damage. I curious about what their ships were like but at the same time i was scared and didn't want to be bombed with radiations, so i asked if they could test me at my place/house, they were understanding and with the middle aged man help i was able to stay. There were a few other people being abducted to whom i speak to every day, like relatives. They were brought into the ship instead. After the testing or whatever was done they returned the other people to the house, we were feeling weird but alive and fine. Another human collaborating with ETs came over, and was willing to briefly reply to some of our questions...
1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33806643
>How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?
You recognize a "full blown lucid dream" by your mental clarity, not what you're able to do. In full lucid dreams you have the same kind of sharp thinking as in real life, able to fully self-reflect and process thoughts as in waking life. In what you call dreams ibetween it's more like you're a zombie with a vague notion that there are no consequences for your actions.

>>33807184
If you're religious, you might benefit from thinking lucid dreaming is some kind of magic phenomena, since it will make it feel more real. If you want to just DILD, do the boring basic shit like keeping a dream journal, reality checks, and MILD before bed.

posts.com:
well gents, new year new goals. something i wish to take seriously this year is something i've come to call "wake-sleeping", although i suppose a more fitting name might simply be "lucid sleeping".

the concept is quite simple: remain aware whenever the body sleeps. it would certainly be similar to WILD, except it takes place at bed time, and ends when you would normally wake up; the ultimate goal being, to completely and entirely decouple consciousness from sleep. the most advanced form of this practice, theoretically, would result in one who never lapses in consciousness, 24/7 awareness.

i've made some progress on making this work, but it's obviously hard. it is certainly possible, however, and so i remain confident in its feasibility, but the trial and error is long and grueling.

i will keep updates in these threads as meaningful developments occur, as this intersects plainly with lucid dreaming (engaging in this practice successfully would have a side effect of making ALL dreams lucid).

posts.com:
I accidentally went directly into a lucid dream without even trying
>Woke up in the middle of the night, probably because I took 2 valerian root capsules before bed
>Can't really get back to sleep
>Figure I'll just do some imagination and visualization
>Spend an unspecified amount of time focusing while imagining things, it was a long time
>Ok, time to go to bed
>Lie on my back and relax
>Hypnagogia starts almost immediately, white fuzz forms into snow falling over a river during nighttime
>Realize what is happening, imagine where I want to be
>I am in my house, it's the middle of the day, for whatever reason I am short, as tall as a toddler
>There are people yelling outside (my room is on the second story), I look down at them, my relatives have arrived in a couple trucks, decide to go out of my room and look around the house as a small person
>My cousin is outside of my door, she is much taller than me
>Can see up her skirt, slap her ass and run past her, she doesn't notice
>Walk around my house for a bit, neat seeing how it is from this tall
>I lose focus and the dream shifts into black. At this moment I don't put in the effort to shift it back into something and just wake up
So overall I knew I was dreaming and could control what I was doing but for whatever reason I had the feeling that I should wake up and sleep properly, so I did. I'm sure if I was actually planning to lucid dream I would have stayed in there but I was tired and it didn't really matter at the time.
I'm theorizing that spending a bunch of time just "imagining" stuff and getting lost in your fantasy world will vastly improve the chances of entering the right state to do this, this was actually the first time for me being in the hypnagogic state and I didn't even try for it.

posts.com:
>>33878876 >>33878852
your mind doesn't fall asleep all at once, it follows a very specific route
as you relax at first proprioception will be turned off [your ability to feel the position of your limbs] then nociception and thermoception turn off [your ability to sense pain and sensing temperature] and finally kinesthesicepion and equilibrioception will turn off [your ability to feel motion and your orientation]
while there are more things that turn off after these two, those two are almost a perfect setup to either fall asleep right there or just enter a wild
i used to have a really hard time falling asleep until i figured this out dayo

I'm not exactly sitting on a super-computer here, but my best guestimation is that beyond the event horizon time becomes a spatial dimension.
i.e., all roads lead to the singularity, there's no direction you can possibly travel that doesn't end up there.
Though, hypothetically, if you were to somehow survive that descent, you could turn around and look back out, and you'd see the entire history of the universe flash before your eyes. That's a consequence of this.
Then there's the matter of the singularity itself. I don't have any idea what that is. My crude calculations just fucking break.
So, maybe it's literally the entire universe, or maybe it's time compressed to such a degree that everything goes 'backwards' in an instant. In other words, the entire lifetime of the entire universe plays out backwards in time as we know it, and you end up at the big bang. The shortest possible increment of time inside is the largest increment of time outside.
Information isn't destroyed if it's send "back" in time... It only appears to be because it's suddenly outside of our causal horizon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What we really need is the ability to produce tiny black holes to study how they evaporate.
This would tell us a great deal about their inner workings.
The problem with studying the evaporation of black holes is that the bigger they are, the longer it takes them to evaporate.
A black hole with the mass of say, a baseball, would take billions of years to evaporate. That's not a convenient time frame for us.
What we need are black holes with the mass of say, an electron.
Then we could watch them evaporate in real time.
It is in principle possible to do this, though it's not exactly practical. We just need some kind of particle collider the size of the orbit of Mars.
We're obviously not going to build that, so we need some other option.
It doesn't actually have to be a solid tube that size, I mean, space is already a vacuum...
Again, I don't have the computing power to really see this through, but there's a faint glimmer of hope that we could somehow accelerate particles to relativistic speeds in orbit around the sun using some kind of high power EM beams to aim them at one another.
This technology is... well, it's frankly beyond us at this point, but in principle it's possible.
If we could like, build a laser array with more power than the nuclear stockpile of all of Earth, and somehow aim it to the precision of an atom at a distance of a planetary orbit, we could construct a sort of 'free floating' atom smasher that could do this.

It’s kind of embarrassing that random nobodies can think up states of affairs better than the one we actually live in. And in fact most of them can’t. A lot of utopias sweep the hard problems under the rug, or would fall apart in ten minutes if actually implemented.

But let me suggest a couple of “utopias” that don’t have this problem.

– The utopia where instead of the government paying lots of corporate welfare, the government doesn’t pay lots of corporate welfare.

– The utopia where every country’s military is 50% smaller than it is today, and the savings go into infrastructure spending.

– The utopia where all hospitals use the same electronic medical record system, or at least medical record systems that can talk to each other, so that doctors can look up what the doctor you saw last week in a different hospital decided instead of running all the same tests over again for $5000.

I don’t think there are too many people who oppose any of these utopias. If they’re not happening, it’s not because people don’t support them. It certainly isn’t because nobody’s thought of them, since I just thought of them right now and I don’t expect my “discovery” to be hailed as particularly novel or change the world.

Any human with above room temperature IQ can design a utopia. The reason our current system isn’t a utopia is that it wasn’t designed by humans. Just as you can look at an arid terrain and determine what shape a river will one day take by assuming water will obey gravity, so you can look at a civilization and determine what shape its institutions will one day take by assuming people will obey incentives.
“

>>33877653
Doesn't make any sense. I know people get interested in just how cool it looks, but keep in mind that nature can make some pretty awesome, unearthly things like that. Doesn't always have to be us.
Atlantis makes a lot more sense when you consider the several candidates of islands that would have suffered catastrophic flooding as the Ice Age first started to end. Particularly when the ice dam in Canada broke; that wouldn't have been a gradual rise in sea levels.
The eye of the Sahara is extremely cool, but also what we expect from something like a salt dome (or other material) expanding and collapsing over time, which is something it would do in an area with volcanoes.
The eye of the Sahara would have only been even further away from the sea at the time of Atlantis - though, it would have been a lot more habitable as most of the Sahara was.
Baiae, the Ancient roman city is a good example of a place that experienced sudden uplift and sinking over and over due to nearby volcanoes - it's currently underwater, but also currently in the process of rising out of the water again.
Pic are some salt domes that have not had that same uplift and collapse process, but you can see how they are very circular. Salt is not the only material that can do this, but it's the most common. Nature also like geometry and neat shapes, especially in geology.
It also doesn't really line up with the accounts of Atlantis and some of the unspoken science behind the mysterious genealogical evidence that people don't like to talk about. All from people who suddenly popped up around the time of Atlantis's supposed sinking into the sea, with the story that they arrived by boat once their civilization sank into the sea. That points to something in the Atlantic that would have been above ground approximately 14,000 years ago, and there's more than one candidate island that fits the bill.

>>33879622
One interesting potential location is actually closer to North America than Europe, but still very close and lines up with the aforementioned genealogical evidence as a start point. There's also a neat backstory to it that I find pretty compelling.
You've probably heard the Basques come up more than once with Atlantis. One lesser-known way they do is directly from the account of a Spanish explorer (I think it was Magellan, but I'd need to recheck). He was in the Atlantic in a completely new unexplored area and was quite proud of being the first there - until he saw a ton of Basque fishermen around. They told him they had been going out there since as long as they could remember, and it was an excellent spot to catch codfish.
That area also happens to be a place that would have been a fairly large island about 14,000-18,000 years ago. That's the reason it had so much fish.
The Basques and Irish Celts have an interesting genealogical connection and both have a backstory of coming by sea from a collapsed civilization - and both are known to be expert seamen.
This is also interesting because it would mean that hypothetically, some of them could have gone the other direction and ended up in North America. It's closer, but to be fair, ocean currents and winds would have actually favored them going toward Europe so it would make sense why so many ended up not going that direction.
The area from that explorer's account with the Basques is highlighted in pic and is the furthest north to the left. But I highlighted another example area that would have also been an island at the time and makes a realistic launch point based on the story of Atlantis and that genetic evidence.
Note: These places could have also had much more favorable temperatures than you'd think due to the gulf stream and ocean currents bringing warmer water in their direction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33879630
I'm a geologist and that is very much a natural structure. I know that people don't always associate symmetry with "natural" but that's a mistake to do especially once you get into geology.
That's not to say that humans couldn't have inhabited it - I'd be surprised if they didn't especially back when the Sahara was more of a temperate climate rather than a desert - which was still around the time period we're talking about and a bit before.
But it wasn't constructed that way, it was naturally there. It also wasn't anywhere near the sea and even back during those higher moisture climate periods, it wouldn't have had constant water flow to warrant calling it an "island" at any point.
It also would have made a much better trade post or temporary settlement (which fits in better with the people we know inhabited the place, even in ancient times there's more evidence of nomadic herding and hunting). Even back in more hospitable climates, it would not have made a good place to set up a permanent settlement because farming would be very difficult due to how inconsistent water would be and how poorly it would drain whenever it did come around.
Again it's a really cool-looking dome feature with an interesting geological history but not everything symmetrical and unworldly looking comes from human hands. Basalt columns are probably the best example of that.

The quality of the photos is the biggest giveaway for multiple reasons.
The film was not stored with any kid of lead protection at all. Passing through the van Allen radiation belt would have "exposed" the film rendering it useless.

The photos are taken with perfect clarity. These are manually focused cameras with viewfinder and the photographers were supposedly holding the cameras at chest height. They took all these perfect photos without using the viewfinder and by manually focusing with those heavy gloves.

In addition, the foreground and background are both in focus.

As for the video, it's slowed down 1/3rd speed. Would we move faster or slower if we went to a moon with more gravity? Their equipment weight wouldn't be a factor because the moons gravity was supposed to be less than 1/7th that of earth. Which means for them to walk at normal speed, their gear would have to weigh 6 times their own weight, but it was in fact less. But let's be generous and say the astronaut weighed 175 pounds and his gear was another 175 pounds on earth. Doing and Not Doing.
A tree is a tree because of our Doing
When the Buddha looked up through the Bodhi tree he reached enlightenment.
He achieved this by NOT looking at the tree but by looking at the spaces between the branches and leaves and joining these spaces together.
Hence he was NOT looking at the tree. He was NOT Doing.

Using two eyes to see.
This is also confirmed by Marco Polo`s account of Genghis Khan.
We are trained from birth to focus our eyes such that our two eyes form one image. But we have two eyes and should therefore see two separate images. If you relax your gaze and separate the one image into two images then the space inbetween is an illusion and the feeling you get from this illusion is what is important.

>>33876571
This world has a lot of "attention economy" characteristics.
It's not always about the quality of your stuff, as much as the amount of eyes on it, and the appearance of success.

Remember dead internet theory?
They prop up some bands and touring projects on youtube with hundreds of thousands of fake views and fake comments. Unironically.
The hundreds of thousands of views translate to the "appearance" of "popularity" to the regular person, who, with the deluge of access to things that they have, assume that thing is popular, and therefore good/worth the investment of time.

Remember that experiment with the world class violinist who performed in the NYC subway?
Tens of thousands of people walked by, he got about 30 bucks in tips, and only about 2 people recognized him, and 12 or so stopped and listened for a minute or two.
The very next day he sold out an ampitheatre of 5 thousand seats, 150 dollars a seat, I think literally in the same city.

Why?
Attention economy. The human brain becomes fickle with so much information and access to so much.

So, what do you do with that info?
Well, first, you realize it very likely isn't a problem of skill, on your part. How good would you have to be to get attention without branding yourself well?
Well, like the violinist, you could be world-class, and you still wouldn't get it.

You can use the attention economy tactics or not, but don't think the lack of attention you're getting for your work is a reflection of your proficiency. It's probably not.

Post your stuff and your website.

before you sleep, write about what you wish to dream of for about an hour. think of nothing else, as soon as you stop writing attempt to sleep and think only about what you have written, repeating it in your mind
when you wake up, record the events you remember; this will help you to build the ability to retain your own dreams
be warned: control over what you dream is not control over your dream. your unconscious mind, your automatic mind, takes over completely. in being unable to recognise that you are dreaming you become unable to conceive of yourself as a thing which can be controlled by itself, and thereby you give yourself over entirely to your subconscious. however, this can be a path to greater consciousness - consciousness is founded upon awareness of that which functions beyond the conscious mind. to know your nervous system is to empower your mind, but if one's mind is split between the productive and the repressive, if the conscious mind functions as pure superego and retains despotic control, to dream can be to unleash greater horrors and an act of existential terrorism. do not give yourself over to dreams, either - to surrender to the unconscious is an act of death, a reduction of yourself to an animal void of higher consciousness. do not debase yourself by the foolish pursuit of 'free desire'

New age is neo advaita. So advaita Vedanta but without the Hindu nomenclature.
Sadhguru is a yogi. Which is one of the main"branches" of Hinduism that leads to liberation. Or moksha.
I too, am a follow yogi, and have elevated my consciousness to higher levels using various forms of Pranayama.
Yoga means union. To unite the duality of subject and object. And attain deep states of samadhi or absorption.
There are eight limbs of Yoga.
>Niyama/yama: observances and restraints.
>Asana: seated position of meditation.
>Pranayama: control of the life force through breath.
>Pratyahara: withdrawal of senses.
>Dharana: Concentration.
>Dhyana: meditation.
>Samadhi: absorption. The no-self awareness state.
Some books to read are self realization and Kriya yoga by Swami yogananda and raja yogi by Swami vivakananda.
>The guru is within.

>>33862072
Becoming a Hollywood actor these days, probably for decades now, essentially selling your soul to the devil. The mega fame and fortune you want has less to do with your talent and more to do with unscrupulousness and lucking out for the big break.

If you want to become a legitimate actor, you are possibly out of luck. "They" control most of the big outlets for getting yourself out there. Suppose you find an independant film-maker: you have to be talented to catch their eye. Great acting entails making the observer believe you are 100% a real person who is (most often) not yourself---bringing a character to life and being compelling about it.

My advice to you would be to give yourself in real life trials. You should enjoy this, based on your chart. Go and interact with random people who don't know you, and introduce yourself as a made-up person who is dissimilar to who you actually are. Pretend to be somebody else and see how convincing you can be, how well you can stay in character, and how much you can move the other people with your performance.

If you can't do this, you can't act, and you're probably only going to succeed by taking lots of cock.

You see, you've skipped out on taking challenges for so long that you don't even know what you're good at and good for. You can see how you've neglected to introspect much in all this time, prefering to just get on with life. But I tell you, it's left you in this place where you have a high amount of self-confidence, but no real plan or experience to back it up.

My advice would be to just try and take a little bit of time to explore potential skills you could pick up. Your talent is in a sense, getting your own way, but that's often the trade of con-men, you understand.

No that anon is partly right, the 12th house is the worst house in the chart and Saturn being in it's joy there doesn't mean it's good for you, it just means the planet can more readily bring about its significations of decline and disaster (from which you can learn!). However interpreting 12th house placements depends very much on the exact chart - having both benefics in good condition in the 12th house for example might mean that you actually defeat and destroy powerful enemies, and profit from it. Meanwhile strong malefic placements in bad condition would indicate being destroyed by one's enemies instead.
You're definitely right on the condition element of things though, especially in a day chart and given a good condition, Saturn in the 12th is the better placement to have than Mars given that it's in its joy.

> Saturn in the twelfth house indicates an uprising of slaves or crises on account of slaves. He may also reduce the native to slavery. Jupiter:
>Greater misfortunes are indicated by Jupiter in the twelfth house.
He always makes enemies who frequently exercise power to hinder the native's activities, especially if a malefic planet is on the ascendant. Mars on the descendant will bring about a violent death.

.
.
The list goes on. I'll summarize how the houses work, for you. The benefic houses are 5 and 11. 5 is the lesser benefic (Venus) and 11th is the Good Spirit (Jupiter). >So how directly were you involved? Was it just through the funding or were you actually physically there in Hong Kong among the protestors?
I was there in Hong Kong throughout the entire event, but I had no direct or indirect interaction with anyone involved in the protests because I was under official cover at the US consulate in HK.

I did however design a large part of the training and indoctrination techniques that were taught and used on the protestors. My biggest contribution was a position I created called "Revolution Consultants" and "People Leaders" which were part of these pro-democracy organizations, and I designed a fake history for these non-profit orgs which involved them helping inspire and set up revolutions to change oppressive government policies worldwide. It was all made to sound really pretentious and appealing to the outspoken "activist" mindset that a lot of these young people had. They were mostly college students.

These so-called revolutionary consultants were at first officers who were under Non-official cover with identities that had no ties to the US government. We communicated with them indirectly and face-to-face briefings would take place outside HK and the mainland in places like Thailand or the Philippines. The officers would then recruit candidates (usually members of student orgs at universities or members of trade unions) to fill out new "consultant" positions, and these guys would find people under them to do the same. In design, it was pretty much very similar to a Multi-Level marketing shill, but designed for "revolutionary activities," It also helped further distance our people further and further from the actual protestors, and the presence of so-many "consultants" and "leaders" with equal ranking helped to decentralize the chain-of-command, which was to prevent everything from going to shit if a large number of them were arrested.

It went to shit anyways, but for a different reason.

>>33848290
I'd suggest that everyone who meditates or wants to start meditating to ask himself the question: Why am I meditating/Why I want to meditate?
So yeah, ask yourself that question.

Ask yourself: Why I want to open my chakras or manipulate energy?

I'm suggesting this because people get into meditation to either chase illusions and other ego-stuff (like goals) or to try and escape from illusions (fears, trauma etc), I think that this is wrong and that meditation should be used for the exact opposite: To realize that all of that are illusions and nothing more.

I'd suggest to just sit and be aware of your body sensations, of your body being there and breathing, not analyzing it or controlling it but totally letting it go and just watching it. This is the basis of the meditative state: Being aware.

But don't put words into it, don't make goals, just do it everyday and stay there.
Depending on who you are this may take some time.

And lastly to also answer your question: You "open chakras" by focusing on them, yeah, meditation is a physical practice not a mental one, you sit to sense and feel so just sit and feel the chakras.

However I'd suggest that first you sit to silence the mind by being still and aware.
Good luck.

>>33853135
>>33853173
There is no division between mindfulness and meditation. Mindfulness is a word that was taken from western spiritual traditions to translate the word "Sati", and it was re-adopted by western society for largely marketing purposes. It's a cozy word. Really, meditation (samadhi) is a focused application of mindfulness (sati). There is no meditation without mindfulness; samma samadhi is the result of samma sati. The Satipatthana sutta is the frame within which all other meditation methods occur in. To be mindful is to keep something in mind, and in Buddhism that's within the framework of the four satipatthana.

I haven't been trained in Zen but I have experience serving retreats at Thai Forest monasteries, where I did read some books on Zazen... the gist I got was that we "just sit to sit" or "sitting is good for nothing". While I can't say how accurate my understanding is, I think this is helpful for times when you get too caught up in goals to the point where you're stressing yourself out, in which case it may be wise to just get back to the bare bones: sitting. But doing that for a while, your mind gets a bit listless or confused, in which case it's helpful to remember why you're practicing in the first place. But sometimes to go deep you have to put aside the part of the mind which is constructing goals and reasons for focusing attention. In a way you have to "just do it". Think Solid Snake in Metal Gear Solid: "Don't think, shoot!"

But in any case, there is mindfulness: remembering to "just sit" or remembering the 16 steps of Anapanasati. You need to read your own mind, so to speak, to see what's good for you. But mindfulness is always there until the end. Sometimes we just get too self conscious about it (which is what the mindfulness industry seems to profit off of).

>>33848290
One of the best uses of meditation is training focused contemplation. You do this through sitting, eyes closed, breathing, and every time you stop paying attention to your breath, you recognize it and pull your attention back to your breathing. It starts with that. Eventually, feel free to let yourself off the leash a little and mentally wander around during your meditation. Something to be cautious of is accidentally developing a dissociative disorder. Be mindful of when that feeling starts to develop and work through it in a healthy way. If you navigate that properly, you have crossed a really powerful milestone in building your skill. If you don't arrive at that point, you haven't been meditating long enough or seriously enough. It's worth getting into, but don't let it consume you. Meditation for me has been at its most beautiful when it feels spontaneous and unplanned. It's ugly when you treat it like it's something you have to pencil in: "oh it's time for my 5 minute 4:00 PM meditation!" When it's just like "hmmm I feel like this is a good time to meditate" that's when I tend to have my best sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33857923
There's a point in that kind of goal-less practice where you're actually kind of just feeding whatever is going on, if you aren't considering your input in the experience. It's like having the TV turned to static and just letting it sit like that forever. Giving your mind an object to focus on and refine, such as the breath "energy", gets you deeper.

But being aware of those things is crucial - you just need to stop giving them input if they're causing too much movement or darker states of mind. Instead of seeing thoughts just as some things which happen, see how they arise due to things within your control (your volitional thoughts and way of seeing things, posture, etc). Learn to use those things to relax the body while brightening and stilling the mind.

Once you've become absorbed in the body, things are much more clearer and expansive. Sometimes there is a sense of great space (you can focus on that to develop it, too).

It's important to balance effort and relaxation here. Too much effort or striving and you just get uptight and frustrated. Too much relaxation, you fall asleep or get lazy and dull. In a way you need to let the breath do the work... "allow it" to soften, fill the body, etc. Release the blockages and tight spots and let the body feel more still.

>>33862655
Some things to look into are the Anapanasati Sutta, the Satipatthana Sutta, Vitakka-santhana Sutta, and the Ahara Sutta (on the hindrances, factors of awakening). They generally have a good framework and a good translation provides good phrasing that's good for remembering.

Balancing effort and relaxation is kind of a thing everyone struggles with on a day-to-day basis and there's no clear-cut way to do it, you have to feel your way into it. But if you develop a somewhat methodical approach to meditation (through continuous practice) it begins to make more sense.

For me I just sit down, get comfy, focus on breathing but also the state of my mind: whether it's contracted or expanded etc (see Satipatthana). Just to get a sense of things. Then I put a little more attention to the breathing and feel it out for tight spots and softer spots. In general the quality of the breath is connected to certain feelings, emotions, thought patterns etc, which may need to be addressed specifically, but sometimes just working with the breath to soothe it and the body is helpful enough. Naturally the body kind of relaxes and the mind gets quieter and more steady.

This is how I do it after a long time of struggling with that balance (although I can't say it's totally "solved" as there is always more room for refinement). At the beginning I was just kind of watching the mind as it is, then after like two years of that I realized I was going nowhere and tried to get a little more methodical. At that point I began to try too hard and get too uptight, so I gradually just began to realize that being observant and "doing" things worked hand in hand. One important thing for me was realizing that much of what we want in meditation are the results. But you don't "get" results, instead you do things which bring results. That entails taking the basic methods, having some goals, and experimenting with the methods to see what happens. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865549
Along those lines, (at least from the Buddhist POV) the key principles are the four noble truths: There is suffering, its cause, its cessation, and the way leading to cessation.

Generally people start meditating because they're stressed somehow or want something better. Right there they may see how suffering is arising as a result of something they are doing. While the root is craving, this manifests as well in thoughts and perceptions we choose to believe.

By experimenting with our thoughts and perceptions in meditation (e.g. replacing thoughts of anger with thoughts of kindness; replacing thoughts of lust with contemplation of asubha or reflection on drawbacks; replacing scattered thoughts with focused thoughts about the breath) we can see how, in turn, those new thoughts or ideas influence the mind to bring it in a new direction.

So the direction of the mind is not something we can latch onto and force one way or another, but rather we need to look at the causes and begin to exert influence on those.

Here is where effort and relaxation again need to be balanced. E.g. thinking of kindness as hard as we can won't generate good feelings and get rid of all of our anger. First we need to be patient and stick with basics, which may just be chanting or repeating phrases from the Karaniya Metta Sutta. Then we need to see what the results are of that over a period of practice.

I often compare it to Tai Chi. In the beginning we must learn basic choreography as well as postural basics. If we speed through the form without basics we can injure ourselves no matter how much we talk about "moving meditation" and "flow". The basics must slowly, gradually, and patiently be developed over time. Then we find that the appearance of flow is only external, and the real internal stuff has to do with our mind and connection to the body, and what we do with that. At first it seems like a lot, but after continuous development it all comes together naturally.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33865632
To simplify: If you're up in your head a lot, just try being more mindful of the body. Do more physical activities (work, exercise, going outside), and meditate on the breath.

Although there's plenty of nuances that need to be developed, sometimes it's helpful to just think of relaxing with awareness of breathing. As we get better and more steady with this, the deeper stuff becomes more doable.

If we find that external circumstances are stressful, breathing meditation may help but from the Buddhist POV we also need to consider our lifestyle and every day decisions to bring us to a better overall place for practice.

>>33853135
I really like that book, first I thought he just had a great editor but if you listen to his talks you can tell that it's his voice. First of all, I think he does a great job at teaching anapanasati, and that by itself takes one a long way. That being said, the book (and I checked out his other material, they are the same) falls short in two ways. One, he seemingly uses metta in his practice heavily, yet the way he teaches that is not great because he tries to teach it exactly as described in the suttas. Second, from what I understood, he exclusively uses kasina meditation in specific ways to go into certain jhanas, yet he only mentions that in passing, as in "oh by the way some people think about circular things while meditating," which makes no sense in the context so you probably brushed that off (I'm not saying that kasina meditation is important and you should do it but rather he doesn't practice what he teaches). This is mostly because how kasina meditation is supposed to be done is not elaborated in the suttas and he doesn't want to go off the book. Both of these issues are caused by the same thing, he's dogmatic about suttas, as most serious Theravadan people.
So to someone who has read that book, I would advise two things. Metta is important, try to find a way to make that work for yourself, both the exact method to do it and how to incorporate that into your sessions. If you're having trouble stilling your mind, this is especially relevant. The second thing is notice the importance of jhanas and the fact that the main goal is to spend as much time as possible in jhana. My understanding based on research is that this is the case and Bhante Gunaratana also teaches this in his other material, but he probably didn't dwell on it in a beginner's book considering that it's an advanced subject.

That's how it is, and I can relate with them because I used to be one of those people: I was raised in an abusive household, tons of beatings and after I grew up and moved out I began using meditation and other "occult" stuff as a way to fix my broken self, all while ignoring everything else - even my childhood memories were tightly kept inside of me and I did everything to never remember them again.

Took me some years to realize that I was just running away from the problem. The solution lies never away from the problem but inside the problem and through it.

So I dropped all practices and began changing basic stuff like my diet, how I spent my free time, changed my hobbies and I only kept meditation, but this time I wasn't meditating to "focus on my anus and this will ground me and I will not fear anymore" but I was meditating to just see what I was and where I were, I meditated in silence to just sit and accept life as it is, after some months I began crying after YEARS during meditations because all those forgotten childhood memories began popping up like mushrooms on a rainy day, I forgave myself and my father during those quiet sits.

After most of my issues were resolved I was way softer as a person, then I began seeing clearly what reality is, how things REALLY work, I could now look at a tree and be amazed that such a thing exists, I was somehow alive again.

Sorry for the wall of text but I like speaking about my short history now and then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fear is our emotional connection to the need to survive. Surviving on Earth has been a traumatizing experience for our DNA, yet we have survived. Steel is forged through fire, and the trials presented to our species through the millennia have made us stronger. Fear was a tool that aided us in this process.

Don't try to purge your fear. Don't think that you can ever be rid of it completely. You must conquer your fear; control it. Think of your fear as your body alerting you to threats. It's a physiological response to external stimuli, and therefore, a product of the mind. The intensity of your fear is the intensity of your own mind. The power of your own thoughts. Instead of trying to stop the river, try to re-direct the flow.

Love and Unity are the key.

posts.com:
So, I thought,
as the door was unlocked
and the landlord disappeared (no,
he actually disappeared)
and I got to examine the room
unobserved. There
it stood
in its gray corner:
the narrow bed, sheets
the color of old aspirin.

Maybe all this had occurred
somewhere inside me
already, or
was just about to.
Is there a choice?
https://youtu.be/iWcQqWW3QCI

Is there
even a difference? Familiar,
familiar but not
yet remembered...
The small narrow bed.
I had often wondered
where I would find it, and
what it would look like.
Don’t you?
It was so awful
I couldn’t speak. Then
maybe you ought to lie down for a minute, I heard myself
thinking. I mean
if you are having that much trouble
functioning. And when
was the last time
with genuine sorrow
and longing to change
you got on your knees?
I could get some work done
here, I shrugged;
I had done it before.
I would work without cease.
Oh, I would stay awake
if only from horror
at the thought of waking
up here. Ma,
a voice spoke from the darkness
in the back seat where
a long thin man lay,
arms crossed
on his chest,
while they cruised slowly up and down
straining to make out the numbers
over unlighted doors,
the midnight doctor’s;
in his hurt mind
he was already merging
with a black Mississippi
of mercy, the sweat pouring off him
as though he’d been doused
with a bucket of ice water
as he lay sleeping. “I saw the light,”
they kept screaming. “Do
I saw the light!”

Ma—there ain’t no light
I don’t see no light.

posts.name: joybunny
posts.com: Someone just died but I'm still alive and yet I don't have a soul anymore. All I have left is a transparent body inside of which transparent doves hurl themselves on a transparent dagger held by a transparent hand. I see struggle in all its beauty, real struggle which nothing can measure, just before the last star comes out. The rented body I live in like a hut detests the soul I had which floats in the distance. It's time to put an end to that famous dualism for which I've been so much reproached. Gone are the days when eyes without light and rings drew sediment from pools of color. There's neither red nor blue anymore. Unanimous red-blue fades away in turn like a robin redbreast in the hedges of inattention. Someone just died,—not you or I or they exactly, but all of us, except me who survives by a variety of means: I'm still cold for example. That's enough. A match! A match! Or how about some rocks so I can split them, or some birds so I can follow them, or some corsets so I can tighten them around dead women's waists, so they'll come back to life and love me, with their exhausting hair, their disheveled glances! A match, so no one dies for brandied plums, a match so the Italian straw hat can be more than a play! Hey, lawn! Hey, rain! I'm the unreal breath of this garden. The black crown resting on my head is a cry of migrating crows because up till now there have only been those who were buried alive, and only a few of them, and here I am the first aerated dead man. But I have a body so I can stop doing myself in, so I can force reptiles to admire me.

posts.name: joybunny
posts.com: Bloody hands, misteltoe eyes, a mouth of dried leaves and glass (the dried leaves move under the glass; they're not as red as one would think, when indifference exposes its voracious methods), hands to gather you, miniscule thyme of my dreams, rosemary of my extreme pallor. I don't have a shadow anymore, either. Ah my shadow, my dear shadow. I should write a long letter to the shadow I lost. I'd begin it My Dear Shadow. Shadow, my darling. You see. There's no more sun. There's only one tropic left out of two. There's only one man left in a thousand. There's only one woman left in the absence of thought that characterizes in pure black this cursed era. That woman holds a bouquet of everlastings shaped like my blood.

posts.name: joybunny
posts.com:
Had we but world enough and time,
This coyness, lady, were no crime.
We would sit down, and think which way
To walk, and pass our long love’s day.
Thou by the Indian Ganges’ side
Shouldst rubies find; I by the tide
Of Humber would complain. I would
Love you ten years before the flood,
And you should, if you please, refuse
Till the conversion of the Jews.
My vegetable love should grow
Vaster than empires and more slow;
An hundred years should go to praise
Thine eyes, and on thy forehead gaze;
Two hundred to adore each breast,
But thirty thousand to the rest;
An age at least to every part,
And the last age should show your heart.
For, lady, you deserve this state,
Nor would I love at lower rate.
But at my back I always hear
Time’s wingèd chariot hurrying near;
And yonder all before us lie
Deserts of vast eternity.
Thy beauty shall no more be found;
Nor, in thy marble vault, shall sound
My echoing song; then worms shall try
That long-preserved virginity,
And your quaint honour turn to dust,
And into ashes all my lust;
The grave’s a fine and private place,
But none, I think, do there embrace.
Now therefore, while the youthful hue
Sits on thy skin like morning dew,
And while thy willing soul transpires
At every pore with instant fires,
Now let us sport us while we may,
And now, like amorous birds of prey,
Rather at once our time devour
Than languish in his slow-chapped power.
Let us roll all our strength and all
Our sweetness up into one ball,
And tear our pleasures with rough strife
Through the iron gates of life:
Thus, though we cannot make our sun
Stand still, yet we will make him run.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From the ages of 15-17 I would have horrific sleep paralysis dreams that virtually every time involved Hitler as the demon.

It wasn't even Hitler as you think of Hitler. Instead of a pudgy 56-year old of average height, this Hitler was probably around 5'2-5'4 and underweight, although had incredibly flabby skin. He looked worn and aged too, but not in a natural way.

I don't doubt that these dreams were the direct product of depression and stress I was facing at the time, but I've never experienced something since so awful.

Imagine for hours each night waking up, forced still in your bed, to a dim room with only the outside lamplight seeping through the curtains. You see a small man pacing back and forth, quietly rambling to himself in the darkness. Some nights this will be the entirety of the dream, other nights, he notices your stares and walks over to reciprocate. Writing this fails to get across how genuinely bad this fucked me up, but you get the point.

had a very very vivid sleep paralysis once, was sound asleep and dreaming normally no nightmares yet nothing out of the ordinary when suddenly in my dream, my eyes start to widen open really hard and suddenly shift into a state of being that resembled real life completely paralysed and heart beating the fastest its ever beaten, i feel someone's hand on my back grab me and whoever it was starts shaking me back and forth semi-violently while reciting what i can only make out as quranic verses to me clear and loud while i am just sat there eyes closed and unable to move a muscle in fear and under the mercy of whoever was behind me.. whole thing lasted like 3 minutes and i woke up in a bed of sweat and a throbbing headache, no words can describe how real it felt. never slept the same for the next 2 months.

>am truck driver
>2am
>tired, in the middle of nowhere
>see an opening on the side of the road, enough for my truck to fit
>park there and decide to take a quick 1hr nap
>spooky as fuck. absolutely no cars or lights. just thick forest
>whatever, im in a big truck. im safe
>go laydown
>keep hearing noises, like something is right outside the truck
>just keep getting this eerie feeling something is watching me and creeping around my truck
>frozen stiff, dont want to move a muscle
>dont know if it was the wind or a branch, but hear something hit the backside of my tractor
>NOPE.jpg
>hop in driver seat and take off
>drive another 200miles before stopping at a truck stop

Feeling paranoid wasn't what made it scary. When I checked my driver-side door in the morning, I noticed the keyhole was fucked up. Like someone tried to brute their way in. I vowed to never sleep in sketchy areas anymore.

On another note, I remember driving at 4AM off some desolate road and saw a man walking butt-naked on the side of the road. There were no exits or other roads for another 30-40miles. I counted. Just a guy walking butt naked, in the middle of winter, at 4AM. Wasn't exactly scary, just very odd. There were no lights on this road either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
first dream I remember having when I was 9 years old
It was a nightmare that was boilerplate for a child that small but what came at the end of the nightmare is what scared me to death, a grim reaper with scythe and 2 ogres on each side pointing to me
2 ogres start to chase me down
I run towards my house (I was down the street of it) and whole house is inverted upside down
I crawl into the window of outside bathroom and lock myself in it
The ogre that ran up to me first start to beat up the door trying to break it down
This is where the nightmare becomes horrible, I start to notice that I am dreaming and that this is a nightmare
Since I understood I was dreaming I tried to wake myself up from the dream by trying to either "struggle" out of it or to "open my eyes" so to say
The ogre succeeds in breaking down the door and looks at me with a smug smile on his green face
He understood that I was trying to wake myself up and he says to me directly
>"Oh? You really think you will wake up?"
>"No, you will die and not wake up"
He slowly starts walking up to me, as if he has already won and knows I will die and not wake up.
I am mortified as I have been trying to wake myself up for what seems to be eternity by now.
He is at arms length now, I am shaking and as he is right in front of me I decide I will at least make peace with my death, not in spite to him festering in my fear or anything like that but just so I will have the calm of meeting the inevitable as I understood it at that time from his demeanor and his words

At that time, as I made peace with it I wasn't afraid to die and I start to wake up.
BUT, that's when the ogre that was at arms length start to try and grab me and screams "noooo, noooo" as if he knew I started to wake up. I wake up and I was so beyond weirded out, I don't believe it was an average dream but more of an interpretation of something higher.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: when I was 17, me and some friends made a DIY diving machine that used two car batteries and an air compressor to pump air down a length of tubing. I tried it once but the pump was sending in a fine mist of pump oil and I couldn't stand it. Our solution was to take one of those snorkel tubes and stuff it full of rags to filter out the oil. The spot we chose to test it out was a decent size pond that connected up to the drainage system of a newly constructed shopping center/strip mall type place. My friend goes in with the new filter and he is going right towards the large black plastic corrugated drainage tube. all of a sudden, the tubing jerks and a whole bunch of bubbles blast out of the water. the line, still belching air, was separated from the snorkel and my friend was gone. He had gotten sucked into the drainage tube sideways and was blocking the flow like a log jam. Some how he got loose but when he did he got sucked down the drainage tube out to where it opens up into a ditch by the street. Miraculously, he was able to hold his breath and come out alive at the other end. From Our perspective, he had just disappeared and he didn't come back up. We went in looking around the edge of the pond trying to find him, hoping that he was just playing a joke and that he had swam away unseen somehow. It didn't make sense but we where so desperate and scared we couldn't understand at the time. Minutes since he disappeared, two police came and hollered at us, and when we looked over, our friend was with them. He was wearing his shirt tied up around his waste, tied up like a loincloth, with a decent gash across his chest from where he was pressed up against the pipe. Later, he recalled that his pants had been torn off, and he was gasping for air, half naked, in a huge rocky ditch where the police happened to see him as they where driving by. Nothing can describe the terror I felt when I realized that he wasn't going to come back up. It is incredible that He is still here.
